Don't buy anything OTHER THAN IBM/Lenovo ThinkPad T, X, and W/P Series if you want the Real Business Experience:tm:
>Other business laptops are welcome in /tpg/ (Dell Latitude/Precision, HP EliteBook/ZBook).

Libreboot-compatible models:
>T60 (check lcd), X60(s/t); X200(s/t. -s requires soldering), T400(s)/500; W500
Models before *40 series and T440p can be Corebooted

Classic models:
>X220/X230 - 12", 768p, cheap and light
>T420/T430 - 14", 900p, widely available, socketed CPU, both Coreboot-compatible (Ivy Bridge CPU support on T420); Quad Core Compatible, Old keyboard swap on *30 series
>T520/530; W520/530 - 15", 1080p, DTR, 32GB RAM on quad core models
>T440s - best price/performance ultra portable
>T440p/540p; W540/1 - Last Thinkpads with socketed processors, easily replaceable track pad (W541 doesn't need track pad replacement)
>T480 - last "real" ThinkPad, battery bridge system, excellent performance/battery life, getting cheaper and cheaper

Upgraded models:
>X210 - X200/X201, i5 8250u quad core
>X62 - X61, i5 5250u
>T70 - T60, i7 7700 hq
IPS displays, USB 3.0, m.2 x4, mini dp, no
https://forum.51nb.com/forum.php?mod=forumdisplay&fid=117

Why ThinkPad?
>Used machines are plentiful and cheap
>Excellent keyboards, tactile feel and quiet
>Great durability: magnesium roll cage for structural integrity, with high quality plastic body panels
>Utilitarian design: e.g. indicator LEDs, 7 row keyboard layout on older models
>Docking stations that easily turns your laptop into a desktop
>Easy to repair (most models), upgrade & maintain thanks to readily available service manuals for every model, spare parts easy & cheap to obtain
>The best TrackPoint:tm: , great for those who type a lot or hate swiping their fingers all over a touchpad
>Excellent GNU/Linux & *BSD support

Welcome to /fglt/ - Friendly GNU/Linux Thread, Radium edition.

Users of all levels are welcome to ask questions about GNU/Linux and share their experiences.

*** Please be civil, notice the "Friendly" in every Friendly GNU/Linux Thread ***

Before asking for help, please check our list of resources.

If you would like to try out GNU/Linux you can do one of the following:
0) Install a GNU/Linux distribution of your choice in a Virtual Machine.
1) Use a live image and to boot directly into the GNU/Linux distribution without installing anything.
2) Dual boot the GNU/Linux distribution of your choice along with Windows or macOS. (They suck though.)
3) Go balls deep and replace everything with GNU/Linux.

Resources: Please spend at least a minute to check a web search engine with your question.

$ man %command%
$ info %command%
$ %command% -h/--help
$ help %builtin/keyword%

$ apropos %something%

threads.com:
https://en.everybodywiki.com/Benefits_of_user-replaceable_batteries

obsolescence
In portable electronics, the battery is the component with by far the shortest life expectancy, thus supposed to be modular and replaced like brakes and wheels on vehicles upon expiration.

Battery aging
Over time, with normal usage, a rechargeable battery wears down and loses both capacity and performance. Each charging and discharging cycle adds to the weardown.

On devices powered by Lithium-Ion batteries, the most common battery type in portable electronics, the battery performance's decline usually becomes noticeable after two years of normal usage or one year of heavy usage. Although the battery should have around 80% of its original performance at that point, it means that it is approximately at the middle of its lifespan.

Power starvation
Unexpected poweroffs
At one point after enough usage, a battery is weakened by its age so much that the voltage risks falling below a threshold (e.g. 3.0 Volts for mobile phones) during normal operation, unexpectedly causing a poweroff. The battery is considered to have reached the end of its useful (functional) lifespan at that point.

Limited performance
Due to the low performance of aged batteries, a device has to artificially limit its processing power to avoid overwhelming the age-weakened battery. Colder environmental temperatures that slow down the chemical reactions inside the battery and lower charging states decrease the output power limit even further.

To prevent this power starvation effect, the device would have to be connected to an external power source such as a wall charger/power supply or a power bank, from where it should be able to draw power in abundance, provided that the power source

Because smaller and more aged batteries are weaker, powering the same tasks and charging at the same absolute speed induces more stress onto the battery cell due to higher power requiremnts relative to the battery's strength.[2][1]

The server end of Snap is proprietary, the client can't disable auto updates (kek), and it's specifically designed to only be convenient for Ubuntu users, despite technically being distro agnostic. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
If you want a lot of computing power for a lower price and you want to learn a little more about your computer, building it yourself is a great idea. You might be able to take advantage of a lot of computing power if you're a 3D modeler, or video editor, or you edit massive images in Photoshop professionally or something.

If you're just going to browse the internet and perform simple tasks with your 'pooter, you won't need the extra horsepower, and the only reason to build it yourself would just be for the fun of building a computer. threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: What is the best way to learn Python/C up to a point where you can ace a tech interview? I want to have more career options after this pandemic.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>75796830
>Up to a point where you could ace a tech interview
Do a website like codecademy to get an idea of syntax and extremely basic problem solving. Read a book like "Automate the boring stuff with python" and do the projects, they're all geared towards beginners.
Read "fluent python" and likewise if there's any exercises.
Read up on basic data structures and Algorithms, then make a few "real world" projects based on everything you've learned so far. Now you're comfortable enough to say you can "code" but not interview ready. Watch interview videos, and do TONS of hard code problems for interview practice like on leetcode.
When you finally understand that it's not just "learn a language well and get a job", find out what python frameworks or libraries a given position is using, and make a few CRUD apps. Should take less than 6 months tops.

threads.name: HDD Read/Write questions
threads.com: How exactly does the RW head change the magnetic polarization of the disk? Does current flux flowing through the head define a '1' and does the lack of such define a '0'?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>75798619
>>>/g/sqt
You could literally google this

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>75798619
For reading they use the giant magnetoresistance effect https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giant_magnetoresistance and measure the resistance. If the magnetization of the layers is antiparallel than it's going to be a lot bigger. It's easy to set the layers to parallel magnetization with an external magnetic field, but Idk how they create the antiparallel configuration.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>75798619
They use an H-bridge to control the direction of current flow through the write head. Reversing current flow reverses the magnetic field polarity; magnetizing points on the disk in one of two directions. If it was just magnetized vs no magnetization you could write a 1 over a zero but not the other way around.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>75800099
Affinity is good and I bought it on iPad, it’s better than full Photoshop for iPad. It was half price at the time too.

Here is the problem with Affinity and why it cannot win the photographer market: it is not subscription based, and no competitor for Lightroom.

Without those two things, Photoshop will reign (comes with Lightroom now).


There are a lot who bitch, whinge and complain about it being subscription, but you’re only going to hear those people being vocal, not the rest of us using it.


The cloud based lossless editing and proofing and sharing workflow cannot is unrivalled and beats the pants off traditional desktop lossy only workflow.

Before this in normal Lightroom, or another app, even with batch editing, you’d have to get home, import and digest images into it, then manually upload your preview images, let someone pick them, make sure you select the same images in Lightroom, edit them, wait for render and export to image files, manually upload them to something, send link to person for review, if any changes wanted, do all that shit again.

Subscription model? Plug sd reader into iPad, import into Lightroom into an album, and start syncing it to the cloud automatically, it’s done before you’re home and you can give a proofing link directly from Lightroom to a person - skips export and render time, manual upload and wait times.

That person selects what they like and you can automatically make another album from that within Lightroom - no need to select by hand.

You can make edits, the images are already synced to the cloud, the images don’t need re-uploading, just the edit metadata.

You can share that album directly with a person via a link from Lightroom without need for render, export, upload.

Any changes? They can be an instant adjustment with very little work.


The workflow is vastly superior and can be done from an iPad (or Android tablet too, Affinity has no Android app though).

I'm part of a university student team that designs racecars. People looking to join can go in one of three streams, based on whether they'd like to develop the frame/steering/mechanical aspects, the power and control system, or if they want to join the team that pitches it to businesses. Until last year, there were 33 people but this year the team's popularity exploded and many more joined.

When it was just a few people, all management was done exclusively through WhatsApp. I know it's terrible, but bear with me. Predictably, when more people joined, the old system of collaborating through WhatsApp turned into a fuckfest. As of right now, there's 17 different groups I'm a part of and I'm not even in Power Systems.

This year it falls to me to manage people, so what I was thinking of was using something like Discord. Have all communications centralized, but different channels and roles to not make the thing a fuckfest like it was. The thing is, no one wants to use Discord because of its privacy issues, since the data we have should be pretty private and secure. I'm looking at a few alternatives, but I can't seem to decide on one.

Online I've read that you should set up Mattermost, or RocketChat, or Wire. The problem is, we have to get everything approved by the university before we do it, and paying for web hosting isn't an option because the university is a crusty old fuck and doesn't hand out money. (South Asian university btw, which you've probably already guessed). So I'm kinda stuck. My requirements are(in order of priority): 1. Roles/Channel system like Discord, or something very similar.
2. Centralized if possible, but FOSS.
3. Able to share images and voice call if possible.

Is there anything at all that I can use? Any help would be appreciated.

I've checked with admissions, and I'm 99% sure I could take comp sci/math classes as a non degree seeking student, finish the required classes, and apply to the MS program (granted my grades are good and I can do some research). last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
“Data Analyst”. I mostly write queries in BigQuery that pull from all of our data sources (Apps, website, Amazon sales, retailer sales, customer service, product registrations, etc) .
I build tables that I then build interactive “dashboards” (god I hate that word) on top of for upper management to look at.
To tell you the truth, I don’t think it’s actually very useful for the people who are using it. It’s not that it *couldn’t* be useful, but nobody looking at the data I present knows what to do with it. They just ooh and aah. I don’t care though, I still get paid and the work is interesting and challenging.
As far as coworkers go, I was been blessed to be a one man show for the first year and a half of my career (3 years in now), so I never have had to deal with bad code or anything. My boss is a great guy who is one of the most technically proficient people I’ve ever met, although he is a workaholic and is very anal about consistency across code and my “dashboards”. That consistency though is important when you’re trying to manage terabytes of raw data I guess.
My two colleagues that work parallel to me are Indian women. They’re mostly competent and easy to get along with, although one of them has the single most annoying voice in the history of mankind. When she speaks it’s like someone is crashing a pair of cymbals right next to my ears.
Thank you for coming to my Ted talk
